Loving Cup Will Be Presented to Winner and to Runner-up.

With winter apparently entirely
gone, everyone's thoughts are turning to the spring sports. Already
the lacrosse and baseball teams have
begun intensive work and now the
tennis enthusiasts are preparing to
get into action.
Wilson Duffy, captain and manager of the tennis team, has decided
to start the tennis season going
with the biggest tournament ever
held at Hopkins. Much interest is
being evidenced on the part of the
students, and it is thought that not
less than 75 or 100 entries will be
listed. Sometime in the near future
a card will be placed in every man's
box. Those wishing to compete in
the tournament will fill this out and
turn it in to the place designated on
the card. The entrance fee will be
50 cents, just enough td cover the
expenses of furnishing balls for the
matches.
The first round of the tournament
will take place as soon as the
weather permits the caretaker to get
the courts into shape. Rules for the
matches will be posted in conspicuous places in all the buildings. The
names of the contestants and the
order in which they play will be
Posted as soon as possible after all
the applications for entrance are
turned in.
As a special attraction two loving
cups will be presented, one to the
winner and one to the runner-up.
Captain Duffy expects the tournament to show up some new material for the team, which should be
very strong this year. Foui- of last
Year's team will be back as a nucleus upon which to build. Jean
Hofmeister, a promising prospect in
the freshman class, ha.'-been elected
assistant manager.
Although the schedule that is being arranged is extremely stiff,
Captain Duffy feels sure that the
season will be very successful.

The Medical Standard Book Co.

MUSICAL CLUB PERFORMS AT
ANNAPOLIS

THE TOCQUEVILLE ORATORICAL
CONTEST

(THE BOOK MART)

One of the largest and best concerts of the year was given by the
combined Musical Club on last Saturday night at the Circle Playhouse,
Annapolis. It was the first trip of
any importance taken by the club
this year, and it seemed to "pep"
the members up considerably,
judging from the way the concert
went off.
The Glee Club opened the concert by singing the "University
Ode." Also this club sang "The
Crossbow" from "Robin Hood,"
"College Medley", "Gipsy Sweetheart" and "Come Seniors Wise
and Learned." The quartet sang
the "Cornfield Medley" awl
Got Shoes." "Johnny Smoker"
was again sung by eight members
of the Glee Club. The orchestra,
Mandolin Club and Jazz Orchestra also rendered several selections. Mr. Fred Wilson sang two
solos, Mr. Sims gave a cello solo,
and Mr. Frankwich played on the
balaika.
Preparations are being made for
the Homewood concert and dance
on Friday, March 17. Students
who have paid their non-athletic
fee will receive a ticket free of
charge upon presentation of their
non-athletic card. Additional tickets can be procured at the price
of fifty cents.

Of all the undergraduates in the
United States five only will receive the Coubertin medals for
1922. One of these five will be a
Johns Hopkins student, for Hopkins is one of the few American
colleges chosen by the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin, a French
publicist and historian, to receive
dnnually a medal to be contested
for in public discussions of matter's pertaining to modern French
history, politics or literature. The
prize to be awarded at Johns Hopkins is known as the Tocqueville
Medal. As has been the custom
in recent years, it will be awarded
to the winner of a contest in oral
discussion at an assembly in the
latter part of April. The subject
for this year will be "France as a
Democracy." Each speaker will discuss some one aspect of this general topic. Suggested sub-topics
suitable for such discussion are
the following:
The French electorate.
The Powers of the French
Premier.
The French Parliament.
Popular Education in France.
To What Extent is France a
True Democracy?
Preliminary trials for the selection of contestants for this medal
will be held March 30 at 12.30
P. M. in Room 112, G. H. The
speech in this preliminary trial
must be original and must not exceed five minutes in length.

PHYSICAL TRAINING NOTES

The Physical Training Class
has finished its course in Hygiene
and has again returned to outdoor
work. Beginning January 9 all
first and second year men had
been reporting regularly to Room
112, Gilman Hall, three times a
week. Here, Dr. Abercrombie had
delivered a course of lectures on
personal hygiene and first-aid.
Now, however, since the weather
has become more pleasant, the
outdoor work has been resumed
again.

Loving Cup Will Be Presented to Winner and to Runner-up.

With winter apparently entirely
gone, everyone's thoughts are turning to the spring sports. Already
the lacrosse and baseball teams have
begun intensive work and now the
tennis enthusiasts are preparing to
get into action.
Wilson Duffy, captain and manager of the tennis team, has decided
to start the tennis season going
with the biggest tournament ever
held at Hopkins. Much interest is
being evidenced on the part of the
students, and it is thought that not
less than 75 or 100 entries will be
listed. Sometime in the near future
a card will be placed in every man's
box. Those wishing to compete in
the tournament will fill this out and
turn it in to the place designated on
the card. The entrance fee will be
50 cents, just enough td cover the
expenses of furnishing balls for the
matches.
The first round of the tournament
will take place as soon as the
weather permits the caretaker to get
the courts into shape. Rules for the
matches will be posted in conspicuous places in all the buildings. The
names of the contestants and the
order in which they play will be
Posted as soon as possible after all
the applications for entrance are
turned in.
As a special attraction two loving
cups will be presented, one to the
winner and one to the runner-up.
Captain Duffy expects the tournament to show up some new material for the team, which should be
very strong this year. Foui- of last
Year's team will be back as a nucleus upon which to build. Jean
Hofmeister, a promising prospect in
the freshman class, ha.'-been elected
assistant manager.
Although the schedule that is being arranged is extremely stiff,
Captain Duffy feels sure that the
season will be very successful.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LET FER, MARCH 14. 1922

4

The Medical Standard Book Co.

MUSICAL CLUB PERFORMS AT
ANNAPOLIS

THE TOCQUEVILLE ORATORICAL
CONTEST

(THE BOOK MART)

One of the largest and best concerts of the year was given by the
combined Musical Club on last Saturday night at the Circle Playhouse,
Annapolis. It was the first trip of
any importance taken by the club
this year, and it seemed to "pep"
the members up considerably,
judging from the way the concert
went off.
The Glee Club opened the concert by singing the "University
Ode." Also this club sang "The
Crossbow" from "Robin Hood,"
"College Medley", "Gipsy Sweetheart" and "Come Seniors Wise
and Learned." The quartet sang
the "Cornfield Medley" awl
Got Shoes." "Johnny Smoker"
was again sung by eight members
of the Glee Club. The orchestra,
Mandolin Club and Jazz Orchestra also rendered several selections. Mr. Fred Wilson sang two
solos, Mr. Sims gave a cello solo,
and Mr. Frankwich played on the
balaika.
Preparations are being made for
the Homewood concert and dance
on Friday, March 17. Students
who have paid their non-athletic
fee will receive a ticket free of
charge upon presentation of their
non-athletic card. Additional tickets can be procured at the price
of fifty cents.

Of all the undergraduates in the
United States five only will receive the Coubertin medals for
1922. One of these five will be a
Johns Hopkins student, for Hopkins is one of the few American
colleges chosen by the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin, a French
publicist and historian, to receive
dnnually a medal to be contested
for in public discussions of matter's pertaining to modern French
history, politics or literature. The
prize to be awarded at Johns Hopkins is known as the Tocqueville
Medal. As has been the custom
in recent years, it will be awarded
to the winner of a contest in oral
discussion at an assembly in the
latter part of April. The subject
for this year will be "France as a
Democracy." Each speaker will discuss some one aspect of this general topic. Suggested sub-topics
suitable for such discussion are
the following:
The French electorate.
The Powers of the French
Premier.
The French Parliament.
Popular Education in France.
To What Extent is France a
True Democracy?
Preliminary trials for the selection of contestants for this medal
will be held March 30 at 12.30
P. M. in Room 112, G. H. The
speech in this preliminary trial
must be original and must not exceed five minutes in length.

PHYSICAL TRAINING NOTES

The Physical Training Class
has finished its course in Hygiene
and has again returned to outdoor
work. Beginning January 9 all
first and second year men had
been reporting regularly to Room
112, Gilman Hall, three times a
week. Here, Dr. Abercrombie had
delivered a course of lectures on
personal hygiene and first-aid.
Now, however, since the weather
has become more pleasant, the
outdoor work has been resumed
again.
